Media Services

Build and deploy end-to-end media solutions with high availability and scalability

Apply for a trial Purchase now

With Azure Media Services, you can transfer any media information anywhere on the world using the cloud on any device. The service set includes encoding, real-time or on-demand streaming, content protection, and indexing for video and audio.

Pricing Details

Encoding Real-time channel Stream processing Content protection Media analysis

Output minutes multiplier

To calculate the total output minutes for an encoding task, the following multiplier will be used.

Mass Multiplier Instances
SD (less than 1280 x 720) 1x 10-minute SD output noted as 10 SD minutes
HD(1280×720 - 1920x1080） 2x 10-minute HD output noted as 20 SD minutes
UHD (greater than 1920x1080, up to 4096x2160) 4x 10-minute HD output noted as 40 SD minutes
Audio output only 0.25x 4-minute output audio noted as 1 SD minute

Example: If there is a QuickTime video with a resolution of 1920x1080p and a duration of 20 minutes, then it is to encode as a mono track MP4 output with the same resolution of 1920x1080p. The effective multiplier will be 2 (HD) plus 0.25 (audio) with a total multiplier of 2.25. The total billing minutes will be (20 minutes x 2.25) = 45 output minutes. If Media Encoder Standard is applied for encoding, the cost will be (45 output minutes x RMB 0.09858/output minutes) = RMB 4.4361

Please refer to FAQs for more examples.

Media Retention Unit

From January 1, 2017, the billing unit for media retention unit will change from daily to hourly, and the price will be lowered.

If the workload requires running multiple tasks at the same time, media retention unit is recommended. The overall throughput of the service can be increased by:

  • Increase the number of media retention unit to achieve parallel processing of more tasks
  • Use faster media retention units (e.g. S3)

For more details, refer to How to Use the Azure Classic Management Portal to Scale Media Processing.

Real-time channel

Real-time channels can stream contents to the audience in a nearly real-time method. There are 2 types of real-time channels: unencoded real-time channel and real-time channel with real-time encoding. All real-time channel types will be billed according to the time quantity of channel time in running status instead of incoming and processed data. Please refer to FAQs for further details on channel status and billing.

Deliver on-demand and real-time video streaming to customers on a large scale in multiple formats. Standard and advanced streaming services can deliver content directly to media player applications or content delivery networks (CDNs) for further distribution.

Streaming stream processing unit provides dedicated bandwidth capacity for on-demand and real-time streaming processing. Real-time channels (utilized with stream processing units) provide real-time streaming capability.

Media service customers can choose standard endpoints or one or more advanced stream processing units according to their needs. The standard stream processing endpoint is suitable for the most workflow-consumed workload. It has the same functionality as an advanced stream processing unit and can automatically scale outbound bandwidth. The advanced stream processing unit is suitable for advanced workloads and provides dedicated, scalable bandwidth capacity. The advanced stream processing unit will "stack", which means that each enabled unit will provide additional bandwidth capacity for the application. The standard stream processing endpoint will not "stack"; instead, it automatically scales bandwidth based on bandwidth requirements. Please visit the Media Service Functions page for more information on the service.

Billing for stream processing is jointly determined by the stream processing service and the amount of data transferred. After enabling Azure CDN through the Media Services Portal or APIs of stream processing endpoints, Standard CDN Pricing applies to all transmitted data. If Azure CDN is not enabled for stream processing endpoints, data transfer is charged according to the Data Transfer Pricing .

FAQs

Expand all
  • What is a media retention unit? What are the benefits of using it?

    Adding a media retention unit to an account ensures that multiple files can be processed simultaneously, and changing media retention unit types can affect the speed with which files are processed. For example, if an account has 3 S1 media retention units, up to 3 files can be processed simultaneously. Changing the retention unit type to S3 will allow faster processing of individual files. For more details, please refer to ourdocumentation.

  • Is the amount of media retention units scalable? Is such scaling restricted?

    Yes, the amount of media retention unit in an account is scalable. Although there are default limits in the Azure portal (For example, up to 25 S2 media retention units are allowed), they are not mandatory. If you require higher limits, please contact us.

  • Do I have to pay higher fees for high-priority jobs?

    No, fees are charged depending on output minutes and the number of media retention units. For more information, please refer to the following examples.

  • If I use the media retention unit, do I still have to pay the encoding fee based on the output minutes?

    Yes, fees are charged depending on the encoding output minutes of the media retention unit. Standard encoder: RMB 0.09858/output minute.

  • Can you provide some examples of coding costs?

    Example 1: Joe uses a standard encoder to process 30 encoding jobs. Each job will create 10 output minutes (300 output minutes in total). Joe uses an S1 media retention unit (RU) which needs 2 hours for running each job. Joe spends 60 hours in a row on the S1 RU and then turns off the RU (setting the number of RUs to zero).

    • Output minutes (standard encoder): 300 x RMB 0.09858 /minute = RMB 29.574
    • S1 media retention unit: 1 unit x 60 hours x RMB 0.13144 /hour = RMB 7.8864d
    • Total cost: RMB 37.4604

    Example 2: Joe uses a standard encoder to process 30 encoding jobs. Each job will create 10 output minutes (300 output minutes in total). This time, Joe uses three S2 media retention units (RUs). Each job will take only 1 hour to complete, so it takes only 10 hours to complete 30 jobs. Joe spends a total of 10 hours in a row on 3 S2 RU and then turns off the RU (the RU number was set to zero).

    • Output minutes (standard encoder): 300 x RMB 0.09858 /minute = RMB 29.574
    • S2 media retention unit: 3 unit x 10 hours x RMB 0.26288 /hour = RMB 7.8864
    • Total cost: RMB 37.4604

    Example 3: Joe has a two-hour movie with resolution of 1920x1080. He uses a standard encoder to encode it with a default “H264 multiple bit rate 1080p” preset to stream movies to iOS and Android devices. The encoding preset generates 3 HD output videos, 5 SD output videos, and 1 audio. The total minutes for this encoding job is (3x2 + 5 + 0.25) = 11.25. Therefore, the total output minutes will be 11.25 x 2 x 60 = 1,350. The total cost is 1,350 x RMB 0.09858/min = RMB 133.083.

  • How much is the charge for creating a thumbnail image
    Both sides of the input video must be consistent with the supported input resolution of each measurement. For example, a video with resolution of 600x481 that exceeds the maximum 640x480 resolution of S1, both sides greater than 480, will be regarded as S2 measurement.
  • If I use two S1 media retention units in a certain period in a day and then use four S3 media retention units on the same day, how do you charge me for that? Do you charge the same way if I use a stream processing unit?

    You will be charged according to the actual minutes of the media retention unit. The following is a more detailed example. Suppose Joe starts with zero media retention units (RUs), and his account is set to use two S1 RUs at 10:00AM that day. In the afternoon came other videos, he changes his account to use 4 S3 RUs at 1:15PM. All videos are processed before 4:00PM, then he closes the RU in the account (setting the RU number to zero). Joe's usage is as follows.

    • S1 media retention unit: 2 units x 3.25 hours (10AM to 1:15PM) x RMB 0.13144 /hour = RMB 0.85436
    • S3 media retention unit: 4 units x 2.75 hours (1:15PM to 4PM) x RMB 0.52576 /hour = RMB 5.78336

    Therefore, the total cost arising out of Joe's use of the media retention unit is RMB 0.85436 + RMB 5.78336 = RMB 6.63772

    Unlike the media retention unit, the charge for the streaming unit is based on the maximum number of streaming units configured per day (high watermarks).

  • If the media retention unit or the stream processing unit has not been used for a period of more than one month, am I going to be charged on a monthly basis?

    No, the charge for the media retention unit is based on the number of minutes, while that for the streaming unit is on a daily basis.

    To understand the cost of coding items, please visit media service calculator page.

  • What is a stream processing unit? What are the benefits of using it?.

    The stream processing unit provides a set of private resources for content stream processing, so that each unit can increase the guaranteed bandwidth throughput up to 200 Mbps.

  • Can I buy many stream processing units?

    Yes, you can buy many stream processing units for content stream processing.

  • If I use two stream processing units in a certain period in a day and then use four stream processing units on the same day, how do you charge me for that?

    You will be charged for the maximum number of stream processing units configured per day. In this example, you will be charged for four streaming units for that day.

  • What is the charge for real-time stream processing?

    The probable value of the current channel may include:

    • Suspended. This is the initial state of the channel after it was created. In this state, channel attributes can be updated but stream processing is not allowed.
    • Starting up. The channel is starting up. In this state, any updating or stream processing is not allowed. In the event of error, channel will return to the "stopped" state.
    • Running. The channel could handle real-time streaming data.
    • Stopping. The channel is stopped. In this state, no updating or stream processing is allowed.
    • Deleting. The channel is deleting. In this state, no updating or stream processing is allowed.

    The following table shows how to map the channel status to the charging mode.

    Channel status Portal UI tags Billed?
    Starting up Starting up No (transition state)
    Running Ready (no running program)
    or
    Stream processing (at least one program is running)    		 Yes
    Stopping Stopping No (transition state)
    Suspended Suspended No
  • Can you provide some examples of real-time channel costs?

    Joe wants to stream a 2-hour sporting event and plans to use real-time channels for encoding...

    1. Joe sets up the channel and starts it 20 minutes before the start of the event. The Channel remains in the “Starting up" state for 5 minutes
    2. After starting up, the channel enters the “Running" state and is ready to receive data streams. The channel will be in the “Running" state (the portal UI indicates the channel is"ready") for 15 minutes.
    3. The event will start to be streamed on time, which will last for 2 hours or 120 minutes (the portal UI indicates "Streaming").
    4. Joe stops the streaming but does not suspend the channel (the portal UI indicates "Ready"). Joe leaves the channel in this mode for 5 minutes.
    5. Joe then streams a post-game show for 30 minutes (the portal UI indicates “Streaming").
    6. After the show, Joe immediately stops the channel and deletes it.

    The channel remains in the “Running" state for 170 minutes in total (15 minutes before the race + 120 minutes during the event+ 5 minutes with no streaming after the event+ 30 minutes for the post game show).

    170 minutes x RMB 40.50/60 = RMB 114.75

  • How is the editor measurement of non-standard video resolution determined?

    Both sides of the input video must be consistent with the supported input resolution for each measurement. For example, a video with resolution of 600x481 that exceeds the maximum 640x480 resolution of S1, both sides greater than 480, will be regarded as S2 measurement.

Support and Service Level Agreements

If you have any questions or need help, please visit Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

  1. For media service coding, we promise that the availability of REST API transactions can be up to 99.9%.
  2. For streaming media, if you buy at least one streaming unit, we promise to successfully process requests for existing media content with 99.9% availability.
  3. For live channels, we promise that the channel being played will remain externally connected at least 99.9% of the time.
  4. For content protection, we promise to successfully process keyword requests at least 99.9% of the time.
  5. For Indexer, we will successfully process Indexer task requests through code-reserved units at least 99.9% of the time.

To learn more about the details of our service level agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreements page.
